name: LOUD and CLEAR Quiz | Wordplay for Kids | 10 Questions

questions.text: Using only letters from "LOUD" and "CLEAR", find a 6-letter word that describes this symbol: $.
questions.explanation:
Dollar.

	A dollar is a bill (or coin) that is worth a certain amount of money.  In the United States, for instance, we have a one-dollar bill, five-dollar bill, ten-dollar bill, and a twenty-dollar bill.  There are other dollar bills we have worth even more, like the fifty and hundred dollar bills, but they are not used nearly as often as the others.

questions.text: Using only letters from "LOUD" and "CLEAR", find a 4-letter word for a running competition.
questions.explanation:
Race.

	A race can be many different things.  It can be a running competition, like a marathon race.  It can also be any kind of competition for speed.  For instance, you might race to see who can eat a pie the fastest, or race to see who can swim to the other side of the pool the fastest.

questions.text: Using only letters from "LOUD" and "CLEAR", find a 4-letter word for something you might do on a phone, to talk to your friends.
questions.explanation:
Call.

	To call someone means to use the phone to talk to them.  People have different phone numbers that you can reach them on, and everybody's phone number is different!  Someone might also call you in for dinner by shouting your name.

questions.text: Using only letters from "LOUD" and "CLEAR", find a 4-letter word meaning a street.
questions.explanation:
Road.

	A road is a type of street that people travel on.  Roads can be made of many things, like concrete or rock, and an unfinished road might be called a dirt road.

questions.text: Using only letters from "LOUD" and "CLEAR", find a 3-letter word meaning not young.
questions.explanation:
Old.

	If someone is young, they have not lived very long.  If they are old, they have lived a long time.  Also, if something is new, it has not been used.  But if it is old, it has been used, and may even be dirty and it might not work as well as when it was brand new.

questions.text: Using only letters from "LOUD" and "CLEAR", find a 3-letter word for a vehicle you might find on the street.
questions.explanation:
Car.

	A car is a type of vehicle that usually has four wheels, and is used to drive on the street, or road.  Cars come in many different shapes and sizes and types.  Cars are sometimes called automobiles or vehicles.

questions.text: Using only letters from "LOUD" and "CLEAR", find a 4-letter word meaning not fake.
questions.explanation:
Real.

	If something is real, it exists.  For instance, a cat is a real animal, but a unicorn is an imaginary (or fake) animal.  Sometimes, people say "really" to mean "very", like "It's really big".

questions.text: Using only letters from "LOUD" and "CLEAR", find a 3-letter word for the "one card" in a deck of cards.
questions.explanation:
Ace.

	The ace in a deck of cards is usually the one card.  It is sometimes the highest card in a game, but sometimes it's the lowest.  An ace is also a type of serve in tennis, where the receiver is not able to hit the ball back.

questions.text: Using only letters from "LOUD" and "CLEAR", find a 4-letter word that means a hint.
questions.explanation:
Clue & lead.

	A clue is a hint given to help you figure something out.  It can help people solve a crime, giving little pieces of information that helps them solve the problem.  For instance, Velma on "Scooby Doo" is able to use clues found by the rest of the gang to figure out who committed the crime.  Clue is also a game that uses clues to help figure out who killed Mr. Boddy, where they did it, and with what.  It is also called Cluedo.

questions.text: Using only letters from "LOUD" and "CLEAR", find a 5-letter word for a white puffy thing in the sky.
questions.explanation:
Cloud.

	The white puffy things in the sky are called clouds, which are made up of a lot of water droplets.  They look light and fluffy, but a cloud can weigh more than an elephant!  Clouds can also be dark grey, and it usually means a storm is on its way.
